Article Highly dispersed MoO x -Ru/C bimetallic catalyst for efficient hydrogenolysis of esters to alkanes Xincheng Cao a Jiaping Zhao a Feng Long a Peng Liu a Yuguo Dong b Zupeng Chen b * Junming Xu a * Jianchun Jiang a * a Institute of Chemical Industry of Forest Products, Chinese Academy of Forestry; Key Laboratory of Biomass Energy and Material, Jiangsu Province; National Engineering Laboratory for Biomass Chemical Utilization; Key and Open Laboratory on Forest Chemical Engineering, SFA, Nanjing 210042, Jiangsu, China Institute of Chemical Industry of Forest Products, Chinese Academy of Forestry Key Laboratory of Biomass Energy and Material, Jiangsu Province National Engineering Laboratory for Biomass Chemical Utilization Key and Open Laboratory on Forest Chemical Engineering SFA Nanjing Jiangsu 210042 China Institute of Chemical Industry of Forest Products, Chinese Academy of Forestry; Key Laboratory of Biomass Energy and Material, Jiangsu Province; National Engineering Laboratory for Biomass Chemical Utilization; Key and Open Laboratory on Forest Chemical Engineering, SFA, Nanjing 210042, Jiangsu, China b Jiangsu Co-Innovation Center of Efficient Processing and Utilization of Forest Resources, International Innovation Center for Forest Chemicals and Materials, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing 210037, Jiangsu, China Jiangsu Co-Innovation Center of Efficient Processing and Utilization of Forest Resources International Innovation Center for Forest Chemicals and Materials Nanjing Forestry University Nanjing Jiangsu 210037 China Jiangsu Co-Innovation Center of Efficient Processing and Utilization of Forest Resources, International Innovation Center for Forest Chemicals and Materials, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing 210037, Jiangsu, China * Corresponding author. The efficient hydrogenolysis of esters to alkanes is the key protocol for producing advanced biofuels from renewable plant oils or fats. Due to the low reactivity of the carbonyl group in esters, a high reaction temperature (>250 °C) is the prerequisite to ensure high conversion of esters. Here, we report a highly dispersed MoO x -Ru/C bimetallic catalyst for the efficient hydrogenolysis of esters to alkanes under 150 °C. The optimal catalyst exhibits >99% conversion of methyl stearate and 99% selectivity to diesel-range alkanes, reaching a high rate of up to 2.0 mmol gcat –1 h–1, 5 times higher than that of Ru/C catalyst (MoO x /C is inert). Integrated experimental and theoretical investigations attribute the high performance to the abundant MoO x -Ru interfacial sites on the catalyst surface, which offers high activity for the C–O cleavage of esters. Furthermore, the dispersed MoO x species significantly weaken the hydrocracking activity of the metallic Ru for C–C bonds, thus yielding alkane products without carbon loss. This study provides a facile and novel strategy for the design of high-performance heterogeneous catalysts for the hydrodeoxygenation of biomass-derived esters to alkane products. Graphical Abstract We report a highly dispersed MoO x -Ru/C bimetallic catalyst for the efficient hydrogenolysis of esters to alkanes under 150 °C. Benefiting from the mild reaction temperature, the C–C bond cleavage side reaction was largely suppressed and long-chain alkanes with high selectivity were obtained. Keywords Bimetallic catalyst Interface engineering Hydrodeoxygenation Fatty esters Diesel-range alkanes 1 Introduction The growing concerns over global climate change associated with the combustion of traditional fossil fuels have motivated great interest in the search for renewable sources to produce chemicals and liquid fuels [1,2]. Biomass represents an attractive renewable resource that can be utilized to produce diversified transportation fuels. At present, biomass-derived transportation fuels have been produced at the level of nearly 2 million barrels per day (MBD). By 2030, this Figure is expected to rise to about 6 MBD, accounting for nearly 6% of the consumed fuels [3]. In this context, the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of plant oils or fats into liquid hydrocarbon biodiesel has attracted considerable attention in recent decades [4,5]. Compared with the ester-based biodiesel produced by base-catalyzed transesterification in industry, HDO has the following advantages: (1) producing hydrocarbon biodiesel with better compatibility with current infrastructures and engines in the absence of oxygen element; (2) no need for the removal of free fatty acids, which are otherwise detrimental to the transesterification owing to the soap formation [6]. Natural oils-derived hydrocarbon fuels are superior to those produced from petroleum because desulfurization and denitrification are unnecessary [7,8]. Triglycerides are the main compound of natural oils, which are esters derived from fatty acids and glycerol. Therefore, the HDO of esters is crucial for the conversion of oils into hydrocarbon biofuels [9–11]. However, esters are more difficult to hydrogenate than various classes of carbonyl compounds due to the less reactivity of their carbonyl group (second to amides) towards the attack of H2 or nucleophiles [12,13]. Although various types of catalysts have been reported for the conversion of esters into hydrocarbons, most of these catalysts (e.g., bimetallic sulfides or supported transition-metal catalysts) require a high reaction temperature to achieve reasonable performance, mainly generating decarbonylation and decarboxylation products with inevitable carbon loss [14–16]. Unfortunately, high temperatures usually lead to the deactivation of catalysts and hydrocracking of the obtained products [11,17], which is unfavorable for the selective synthesis of alkanes. In recent years, bifunctional metal-acid catalysts have been developed and showed high catalytic performance for producing alkanes from plant oils or fats [18–20]. Lercher's group reported good activities of solid acid zeolite-supported nickel catalysts for the HDO of microalgae oil at 260 °C, achieving approximately 78 wt% yields of alkanes [21,22]. However, high temperature (260 °C) and abundant acid sites caused the hydrocracking reaction, which resulted in severe carbon loss. Although the conversion of vegetable oils catalyzed using Pd/NbOPO4 bifunctional catalyst produced alkanes with high carbon yields (~84.0 wt%) at mild conditions (180 °C, 3.0MPa H2) [23], long reaction times (24 h) due to a low reaction rate limited its application. Therefore, the development of efficient catalysts that can facilitate the HDO of esters to alkanes at low temperatures is still highly desired to improve the selectivity towards alkanes and avoid the problem of carbon loss. Anchoring reducible oxides (e.g., WO x , MoO x , and ReO x ) to the surface of noble metals (e.g., Pt, Ir, and Rh) can efficiently facilitate the selective production of different value-added chemicals from renewable biomass resources, and also promotes the cleavage of C–O bonds in me-cresol owing to the synergistic effect of different active sites (e.g., metal sites, Brönsted acid, Lewis acid, and redox sites) [24–26]. Although Ru-Mo bimetallic catalysts had shown intriguing performance for the hydrogenolysis of carboxylic acids [27,28], the structure-performance relationship remained unexplored and their attempts in upgrading long-chain fatty acids/esters or natural oils into diesel-range alkanes with high yields not successful due to the poor dispersion of both Ru and Mo species. Herein, we reported an efficient MoO x -Ru/C bimetallic catalyst for the selective hydrogenolysis of esters to alkanes at 150 °C. The catalyst containing a Mo/Ru molar ratio of 0.2 exhibited exceptional catalytic performance with almost full conversion of methyl stearate and 99% selectivity diesel-range alkanes. Comprehensive experimental and theoretical analyses showed that such high HDO performance was mainly attributed to the unique synergistic effect between Ru and MoO x species, in which the highly dispersed MoO x brought abundant Brönsted and Lewis acid sites for promoting the conversion of esters into alkanes, while the adjacent Ru provided sufficient active hydrogen atoms for the HDO reaction. Compared with previously reported HDO catalytic systems of biomass-relevant esters, our catalyst has the following advantages: (1) maximizing active interfaces for the hydrogenolysis of esters, and (2) mainly yielding HDO products without carbon loss by suppressing the hydrogenolysis activity of Ru towards C–C bonds. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (purity, 99.0%), (NH4)6H2W12O40·xH2O (purity, 99.0%), Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (purity, 99.99%), Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (purity, 98.5%) and SnCl2·2H2O (purity, 98%), methyl stearate (99%), methyl palmitate (99%), stearic acid (98%), glycerol trioleate (99%), undecanoic δ-lactone (98%), γ-dodecalactone (98%), commercial 5% Ru/C, active carbon (200 mesh) were purchased from Macklin (Shanghai, China). It is noted that all chemicals were used without further purification except for the 5% Ru/C catalyst, which was reduced at 400 °C for 3.0 h in flowing of H2 prior to the reaction. Cooking oils were purchased from commercial sources. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The yMoO x -Ru/C catalysts with different molar ratios of Mo/Ru were synthesized by an impregnation-reduction method. Typically, a calculated amount of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O was added into the solution containing commercial 5% Ru/C. The resultant slurry was stirred for 24 h followed by evaporation of the excess solvent at 60 °C. The obtained samples were kept in a vacuum drying oven at 60 °C for 12 h for further dehydration and then reduced at 400 °C for 3.0 h in flowing of H2. The as-prepared MoO x -Ru/C catalysts were denoted as yMoO x -Ru/C, in which y represented the molar ratio of Mo to Ru. Other metal oxide-Ru/C catalysts (including FeO x -Ru/C, SnO x -Ru/C (using ethanol as solvent due to the hydrolysis of Sn2+), WO x -Ru/C, Ni-Ru/C) were prepared by using the same method as the MoO x -Ru/C catalyst. The molar ratio of metal/Ru was 0.2 in all mentioned catalysts unless stated otherwise. In addition, the active carbon-supported monometallic Mo (0.2 MoO x /C) catalyst with the same Mo loadings as the 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C was also prepared by using an identical impregnation method. For comparison, 0.2MoO x -Ru/C(N2) catalyst was synthesized through calcination at 400 °C for 3.0 h in flowing of N2. 2.3 Characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on Bruker D8 (Germany) with Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 0.15418 nm). The distribution of metal elements on the catalyst surface were observed by using a FEI Talos F200X transmission electron microscopy (TEM) ((FEI Co., American). High-angle annular dark field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) was carried out on a JEM ARM 200F transmission electron microscope (JEOL Co., Japan). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on a Thermo Escalab 250XI equipped with an Al Kα X-ray anode operated at 150 W and 14.8 kV. The spectra were referenced to C (1s) at a binding energy (BE) of 284.8 eV. CO chemisorption was carried out on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 apparatus to calculate the metal dispersion. The temperature-programmed desorption of methyl octanoate and hexane was performed on the Micromeritics AutoChem II equipped with a mass spectrometer (MS) to investigate the interaction between catalyst and reactant. Typically, 0.1 g amount of catalyst was pretreated in a He flow at 200 °C for 1.0 h. After the temperature was reduced to 50 °C, the catalyst was exposed to the vapor of the reactant for 1.0 h and then flushed again with flowing He for another 30 min to remove the physically adsorbed reactant. Finally, the temperature was increased to the desired temperature at a heating of 10 °C min–1, and the MS was used to identify the desorbed compounds. X-ray absorption spectra of the Mo K-edge were carried out with Si (111) crystal monochromators at the BL14W beamline at the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility. Before the analysis, the tested samples were placed into aluminum holders and sealed using Kapton tape film. The X-ray adsorption fine structure (XAFS) spectra were collected at room temperature using a 4-channel silicon Drift Detector (SDD) Bruker 5040. The K-edge extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra were recorded in transmission or fluorescence mode. The XAFS spectra of these standard samples were recorded in transmission mode. The spectra were processed using the software codes Athena. Pyridine and acetonitrile-d adsorption FTIR spectroscopy were performed on a Thermo Nicolet 380 FTIR spectrometer to analyze the Brönsted (B) and Lewis (L) acidic sites of the samples. The amounts of L and B acid are calculated according to previously reported calculations [1]. To study the interaction between catalyst and fatty acid esters, the in-situ spectra of the methyl octanoate were performed on the Thermo Nicolet-iS50 FT-IR. Prior to the test, the catalyst was reduced in situ at 400 °C for 1.0 h. After that, the system was cooled to room temperature, and the methyl octanoate vapor was adsorbed on the catalyst surface until saturation. Then, the system temperature was increased from 25 to 200 °C and held at set the temperature point for 10 min under flowing hydrogen. The IR spectra were recorded at 25, 50, 80, 100, 130, 150, and 200 °C. 2.4 Density functional theory (DFT) calculation The spin-polarized DFT calculations were conducted using the Vienna ab-initio simulation package (VASP) [2,3] to study the interaction between reactant and as-prepared catalysts. The Projector augmented wave method [3] with a cutoff energy of 400 eV accompanied by Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof functional [4] was used in the DFT calculations. DFT-D3 method [5] was used to correct the influence of van der Waals interactions. Four layers of Ru (001) facets were cleaved with a vacuum layer of 15 Å to build the slab models. Based on the XAS analysis results, the Ru-Mo3O7 model was built by putting the Mo3O7 cluster on the Ru (001) surface. Half of the bottom atoms in these models have been fixed to simulate the bulk phase. All models have been fully relaxed with the energy convergence criterion of 10–5 eV and the force convergence criterion of 0.02 eV Å–1, respectively. The K-point mesh in the Brillouin zone is 0.04 × 2π Å–1. To obtain the energy barrier of the decomposition process, the constrained ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) has been used. The model has been heated up to from –273 to 150 °C by velocity scaling over 1058 fs with a 1-fs time step. The slow-growth method has been used to control the decomposition process and the collective variable is the distance between key atoms. All collective variables increase with 0.001 Å per MD step. The adsorption energy (E ads) has been calculated using formula (1) (1) E ads = E total – E substrate – E adsorbate The E total, E substrate and E adsorbate represent the energy of adsorption structure, substrate and adsorbate, respectively. The free energies have been calculated using the following formula (2) (2) G = E DFT + ZPE – TS The G, E DFT, ZPE and TS represent the free energy, energy from DFT calculations, zero point energy and entropic contributions, respectively. 2.5 Catalytic performance The HDO of esters was performed in a 50-mL autoclave reactor. Typically, a suitable amount of reactant, activated catalyst, and hexane (10 mL) were added into the reactor. Then, the reactor was sealed and purged with H2 at room temperature three times to remove the inside air. After that, the reactor was pressurized into 3.0 MPa H2 at room temperature and then heated to the desired temperature at a stirring speed of 1000 r min–1. After the reaction, the liquid products were collected and analyzed by GC-MS. The quantitative analysis of the liquid products was conducted by GC (Agilent 7890A/5975C) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and HP-5MS capillary columns (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 µm) through using Eicosane as an internal standard. The unknown products in liquid products were identified by GC-MS (Agilent 6890/5973N) equipped with mass spectrometry detection. To ensure reproducibility of experimental data, every experiment was performed at least two times. The conversion (%) of reactants and the selectivity of products were calculated by using the following Eqs. (3, 4): (3) Conversion = mol initial reactant - mol unreacted reactant mol initial reactant × 100 % (4) Selec. ( detec. products ) = mol product mol all products in detacted liquid products × 100 % The yields of all products from the conversion of cooking oil were calculated on a weight basis by using Eq. (5): (5) Yield. ( detected . products ) = m product m initial reactant × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The yMoO x -Ru/C catalysts with different Mo/Ru ratios were prepared via impregnating ammonium molybdate on Ru/C, followed by reduction at 400 °C in H2 atmosphere (y represents the molar ratio of Mo to Ru). TheXRD pattern of the as-prepared catalysts (Fig. 1(a) ) showed the exclusive peaks of the amorphous carbon and no diffraction peaks associated with ruthenium and molybdenum species were observed, indicating that Mo and Ru species are highly dispersed. The representative TEM image (Fig. 1(b)) showed that the average size of black nanoparticles was ~3.67 nm in 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C catalyst. The HRTEM image revealed the crystal lattice of 0.214 nm (Fig. 1(c)), which could be assigned to the (002) facet of metallic Ru (JCPDS No. 65-1863). The decoration of Mo species did not change the average diameter of the Ru nanoparticle obviously as compared with the Ru/C catalyst (~3.58 nm) (Fig. S1), suggesting the high dispersion of Mo species on the surface of 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C. The content of Mo species was determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) to be about 1.3 wt% in 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C catalyst. Furthermore, the high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) image showed the highly dispersed Mo sites on the metallic Ru surface (Fig. 1(d) and (e), which was supported by the reduced CO adsorption capacity of 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C (0.10 mmol g–1) than that on Ru/C catalyst (0.18 mmol g–1)(Fig. 1(f) and Table S1. In addition, the energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mappings (Figs. 1(g–i)) and HADDF-STEM line scanning (Fig. S2) of single nanoparticles of 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C catalyst further provided direct evidence that MoO x was highly dispersed on the surface of Ru nanoparticles as the Mo and Ru signal align. To figure out the configuration and local coordination information of Mo atom sites, XAFS was carried out (Fig. 2 ). The normalized Mo K-edge XANES (Fig. 2(a)) showed that the feature of absorption edge for the Mo element in 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C was different from the Mo foil and MoO2, while similar to that in MoO3, implying that they have analogous atomic structure. Additionally, the adsorption edge of 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C located between that of MoO2 and MoO3, suggesting that the oxidation state of Mo species in 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C is higher than Mo4+ (MoO2) and lower to Mo6+ (MoO3), which was also further confirmed by XPS (Fig. 2(b)). Fourier transform EXAFS (FT-EXAFS) of Mo K-edge was utilized to analyze the local coordination information of Mo atom sites. As shown in Fig. 2(c), the as-prepared 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C showed a Mo-O coordination scattering peak located at ~1.25 Å. The corresponding FT-EXAFS fitting results (Fig. 2(d)) showed that the coordination number of O atom in the first- and second-shell of Mo for 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C were 2.5 and 1.4, respectively, which were lower than those of the MoO3 reference (Fig. S3, Table S2), indicating that the unsaturated coordination states of Mo in 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C catalyst. The Mo K-edge fitting results showed that the coordination number of Mo-Ru for 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C is 1.6 (Fig. S3, Table S2), which is close to that of 2.0 for the trimer [29]. Wavelet transform (WT) as a supplement for FT-EXAFS could better clarify the Mo coordination environments. As shown in Figs. 2(e–h), the WT contour plots of 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C (Fig. 2(f)) displayed one Mo–O coordination intensity maximum at ~1.3 Å, without other scattering paths compared with the WT plots of Mo foil, MoO2, and MoO3. The aforementioned results suggest that the Mo species were highly dispersed on the surface of metallic Ru in the form of trimer, as illustrated in Fig. 2(i). The acidity of the catalyst plays an important role in promoting the hydrogenolysis of esters into alkanes, in which Lewis acid (L) sites interact with the oxygen atom of the carbonyl group of esters to promote the deoxygenation of esters [30,31], while Brönsted acid (B) sites are conducive to facilitating the dehydration of alcohol intermediates [32,33], thereby improving the alkane selectivity. To characterize the acid type and their concentrations, two kinds of experiments including FTIR spectroscopy of pyridine and acetonitrile-d adsorption were performed. For the pyridine adsorption (Fig. 3(a) ), it was observed that all tested catalysts showed two peaks at 1445 and 1596 cm–1, which can be attributed to the deformation vibration of the C–H and C–C bonds of the adsorbed pyridine at Lewis acid sites, respectively [34]. The peak at 1490 cm–1 could be assigned to both Lewis and Brönsted acid sites [35]. As compared with the Ru/C catalyst (total acid sites: 27.6 µmol g–1), the total acid sites of 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C increased to 42.3 µmol g–1, suggesting that the introduction of Mo species increases the concentrations of acid sites on the MoO x -Ru/C catalysts. Furthermore, FTIR spectroscopy of acetonitrile-d adsorption was utilized to accurately distinguish the acid site type between different catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3(b), two peaks at 2282 and 2276 cm–1 were observed in the tested catalysts, corresponding to the CD3CN adsorption on Lewis acid sites and physisorbed acetonitrile, respectively [36,37]. Compared to Ru/C and 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C (N2) that was intentionally prepared by calcination under the N2 atmosphere, 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C showed a new peak at 2309 cm–1, which could be attributed to the Brönsted acid sites. According to the XPS spectra of Mo 3d (Fig. 3(c)) and O 1s (Fig. 3(d)), 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C contains more Mo5+ species and hydroxyl groups (OH) than 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C (N2) catalyst. It is speculated that the increased acid sites in 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C might associated with its abundant uncoordinated Mo species (Mo5+), in which the number of both Lewis and Brönsted acid sites of the catalysts increased through the formation of Mo5+-OH, in line with the previous studies of Mo/Pt/WO x [31] and MoO x /CeO2 catalysts [38]. 3.2 Catalytic test The HDO of the methyl stearate in a batch reactor was selected as a model reaction to evaluate the catalytic performance of the prepared MoO x -Ru/C catalysts. The commercial Ru/C and a series of inexpensive oxyphilic metals (e.g., Ni, Fe, Sn, W, and Mo) modified Ru/C catalysts were screened first under the reaction conditions of 150 °C and 3.0 MPa H2, among which 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C showed the highest activity for the conversion of methyl stearate (> 99%), yielding n-heptadecane (n-C17) and n-octadecane (n-C18) as the primary products (Fig. 4(a) ). In comparison, the commercial Ru/C and other metals (i.e., Ni, Fe, Sn, W) modified Ru/C catalysts showed poor or negligible activity for the conversion of methyl stearate, demonstrating the crucial role of Mo species for the HDO of the fatty acid esters. Besides, the monometallic 0.2 MoO x /C catalyst was ineffective whereas the Ru/C catalyst showed 23% conversion with n-C17 alkane being the primary product, suggesting that the metallic Ru sites are the main active sites for the HDO of fatty esters. The catalytic performance of a physical mixture of 0.2 MoO x /C and Ru/C was also evaluated as a comparison and showed a similar methyl stearate conversion (27.3%) as the Ru/C catalyst, indicating a strong synergistic effect between Ru and MoO x species in the 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C catalyst. The influence of MoO x loadings on the HDO of methyl stearate was studied (Fig. 4(b)). Compared to the Ru/C catalyst showing low catalytic activity with 23% methyl stearate conversion, the introduction of 0.9 wt% Mo species (0.1 MoO x -Ru/C) significantly enhanced the HDO catalytic performance, giving 93% conversion and 98% total selectivity to n-C17 and n-C18 alkanes. Superior catalytic performance was achieved over the 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C catalyst with >99% conversion and 99% selectivity to alkanes. Further increasing the molar ratio of Mo/Ru to 1.0, the conversion gradually declined to 24% of 1.0 MoO x -Ru/C and the selectivity of stearyl alcohol (C18-OH) increased. The decreased catalytic performance over 0.5 MoO x -Ru/C and 1.0 MoO x -Ru/C was mainly due to the over-coverage of the metallic Ru active sites by the excessive loading of Mo species. Fig. 4(c) showed that 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C significantly improved the reaction rate (2.0 mmol gcat –1 h–1) and the alkane formation rate (0.7 mmol gcat –1 h–1), respectively, which was 5.0 and 7.0 times higher than that over Ru/C. As shown in Fig. 4(d), the catalytic performance of 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C outperforms most of the state-of-the-art catalysts for the HDO of fatty esters especially at low temperatures. To map the reaction pathway for the conversion of fatty acid esters to alkanes, various reaction parameters such as reaction time and temperature were systematically investigated over the MoO x -Ru/C and Ru/C catalysts. As shown in Fig. 5(a) , with the conversion of methyl stearate, the selectivity of n-C17 and n-C18 alkanes increased and got to a maximum value of 99% at 6.0 h. C18-OH as an intermediate was also detected at the initial reaction stage of 1.0 h, and then converted into n-C17 and n-C18 alkanes via the dehydrogenation-decarbonylation and dehydration-hydrogenation routes, respectively. Moreover, CH3OH was also detected as side product, as determined in the GC spectrum (Fig. S4), suggesting that methyl stearate was converted by the cleavage of the acyl C–O bond. The reaction was terminated once the reaction atmosphere switched from H2 to N2 at the conversion of 56%, suggesting that fatty esters were converted through hydrodeoxygenation rather than directly undergoing decarboxylation or decarbonylation reaction. Fig. 5(b) shows the effect of reaction temperature on the conversion and product distributions. At a low temperature of 150 °C, 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C showed high conversion (>99%) and 99% total selectivity towards n-C17 and n-C18 alkanes with n-C18 alkane being the main product; whereas only 23% conversion was obtained over the Ru/C with n-C17 alkane as the main product. As the temperature increased from 150 to 200 °C, the catalytic activity of Ru/C gradually enhanced and achieved 100% conversion and high selectivity to n-C17 alkane (95%) at 200 °C. Further raising the temperature to 205 °C, the resulting n-C17 alkane over Ru/C underwent a severe cracking with 73.0% cracking products after 1.5 h reaction (Fig. 5(c)), while only about 25% cracking products were produced over the 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C even after 2.5 h reaction, implying that adding Mo species can suppress the hydrocracking activity of Ru metal sites. Based on the above results, it is concluded that the HDO pathway is dominant over the MoO x -Ru/C catalyst, while the decarbonylation (DCO) and cracking reaction (CR) are more likely to occur when the reaction was catalyzed over the Ru/C, as shown in Fig. 5(d). 3.3 Substrate scope and catalyst stability The substrate scope of the optimal 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C for the HDO of various esters was further evaluated. As shown in Table 1 , fatty acid esters such as methyl palmitate, methyl laurate, and ethyl palmitate (entries 1–5) can be efficiently converted to corresponding alkanes with > 95% conversion and 90% selectivity. Furthermore, the catalyst could also achieve the quantitative conversion (> 99%) of fatty acids such as stearic acid, palmitate acid, and laurate acid, producing the corresponding alkanes with > 90% selectivity (entries 6–8). This high catalytic activity towards fatty acids and esters suggests that 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C catalyst has great potential to realize the conversion of low-quality oils such as cooking oils, into high-quality hydrocarbon biodiesels under mild reaction conditions. In addition to the linear aliphatic esters, the as-prepared 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C catalyst can also efficiently convert cyclic esters into ring-opened alkane products (entries 9 and 10). The excellent catalytic performance of 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C catalyst for reducing the fatty acids and esters to alkanes allows us to convert natural oils. As shown in Fig. S5, the HDO of glycerol trioleate showed that 84.0 wt% yield of total liquid alkanes was obtained at 180 °C after 8.0 h. When using cooking oils that mainly consist of fatty acid as feedstock (the detailed compositions in Table S4), a high yield of alkanes (83.9 wt%) was obtained at 180 °C, which was very close to the theoretical yield (86.1 wt%) obtained by the calculation equation reported in the literature [23]. Catalyst stability as a key evaluating indicator for heterogeneous catalysts was also investigated using methyl stearate as the model compound. As shown in Fig. S6(a), the catalytic activity of 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C catalyst showed a slight loss (conversion decreased from >99% to 89%) while the selectivity of alkanes remained > 93% after four operating cycles. Note that the reaction was terminated once the catalyst was removed at the conversion of 70% (Fig. S6(b)), suggesting that the HDO reaction of fatty esters proceeds through a heterogeneous process on the surface of 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C. The post-analysis of the used catalyst by ICP-OES, STEM, and EDS elemental mappings evidenced virtually identical metal contents (Ru, from 3.4 to 3.2 wt%; Mo, from 1.3 to 1.0 wt%) and metal dispersion (Fig. S7). These results demonstrate the good stability of the prepared 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C catalyst. 3.4 Insights into the activity and selectivity To reveal the origin of the excellent catalytic performance of the 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C catalyst, a series of in-situ characterizations and computational studies were carried out. The temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of methyl octanoate was first conducted to investigate the interaction between fatty esters and catalysts. As shown in Fig. 6(a) , a much greater desorption amount of methyl octanoate and a wider desorption temperature range were observed over the 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C catalyst in comparison to the Ru/C catalyst. Specifically, the desorption amount of methyl octanoate at high temperature (≥ 350 °C) over 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C was significantly higher than that on Ru/C, suggesting a stronger interaction between the methyl octanoate and 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C catalyst. The methyl octanoate desorption behavior was in agreement with the catalytic performance, in which the 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C showed higher catalytic activity than that of the Ru/C catalyst. The interaction between catalysts and esters was further studied using diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS) upon exposure of 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C and Ru/C to a methyl octanoate/H2 mixture. The reduced catalyst was first treated with 5% H2/Ar at 400 °C before being exposed to methyl octanoate/H2 mixture. As shown in Figs. 6(b,c), the DRIFTS spectra of both 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C and Ru/C showed bands at 1746 and 2860–2990 cm–1, which corresponded to the vibration modes of ν (C=O) and the stretching frequencies of the aliphatic C–H (CH3, CH2, and CH) [39,40], respectively. As the temperature increased from 25 to 200 °C, ν (C=O) showed an obvious shift towards high wavenumber, indicating that methyl octanoate was chemically adsorbed on the surface of these catalysts. Compared with Ru/C catalyst showing a weak peak intensity for ν (C=O) at 250 °C, 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C catalyst exhibited a stronger peak intensity and a significant shift towards the high wavenumber (from 1746 to 1762 cm–1) for ν (C=O), suggesting that methyl octadecane can be more stably adsorbed on 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C via interacting with the carbonyl group of esters. DFT calculations were performed to further elucidate the promotion mechanism of 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C catalyst for the conversion of fatty acid esters. Based on the XAS results, Ru-Mo3O7 was constructed as the model. For simplicity, methyl propionate was used to replace long-chain fatty acid esters as they have the same carbonyl oxygen group. As shown in Fig. 6(d), the adsorption energy (E ads) of methyl propionate was higher over Ru-Mo3O7 (–1.47 eV) than that of Ru (001) (–1.09 eV), suggesting that methyl propionate could be efficiently adsorbed on MoO x -Ru than that on the Ru catalyst, in line with the results of methyl octanoate-TPD and DRIFTS analysis. The enhanced interaction between the unsaturated Mo sites and the carbonyl group of fatty esters over 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C catalyst weakens the energy of the C=O bond, thus promoting the acyl C–O bond cleavage of fatty acid esters. As further evidenced by DFT calculation, the energy barrier of the acyl C–O bond breaking of methyl propionate for the Ru-Mo3O7 is 0.33 eV (Fig. 6(e)), which is lower than that of Ru (001) (0.41 eV) (Fig. 6(f)). To further elucidate the higher HDO selectivity of 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C over Ru/C catalyst, the intermediate C18-OH was used as the substrate. As shown in Fig. S8, the n-C17 and n-C18 alkanes were the main products over Ru/C and 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C catalysts, respectively, suggesting that the dehydrogenation-decarbonylation process is more likely to occur over Ru/C, while the dehydration-hydrogenation process is dominant over 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C catalyst. According to previous work [37], the change in the deoxygenation pathway was mainly associated with the type of acid sites, that is, Brönsted acid sites are beneficial for the selective production of n-C18 alkane via promoting the dehydration-hydrogenation process of the intermediate C18-OH. Based on the above analysis, it is concluded that the high HDO performance of 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C for the conversion of esters can be attributed to the efficient synergy between metal, Lewis and Brönsted acid sites (Fig. 7 ), where Ru metal sites provide active hydrogen atoms for the hydrogenation, while the adjacent Lewis and Brönsted acid sites (generated from Mo5+-OH species) promote the hydrogenolysis of esters and fast conversion of intermediate alcohols, respectively. To gain more insights into the significantly reduced C–C bond hydrogenolysis activity of MoO x -Ru/C compared to Ru/C, hexane-TPD experiments with mass signal (MS) detection were carried out. As the Mo/Ru molar ratio increased from 0 to 0.5, the desorption temperature and the intensity of n-heptane gradually decreased (Fig. 8(a) ), which indicates that introducing Mo on Ru metal can weaken the interaction between Ru and alkanes. As the desorption temperature rises, the n-heptane adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst was converted into three main products: hydrogen (H2), methane (CH4), and propane (C3H8). As shown in Fig. 8(b), the desorption temperature of H2 over Ru/C was 247 °C, which was lower than that over 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C (325 °C) and 0.5 MoO x -Ru/C (318 °C), implying that the dehydrogenation reaction of hexane was suppressed by dispersed Mo on Ru metal. The higher desorption temperatures of CH4 (Fig. 8(c)) and C3H8 (Fig. 8(d)) over 0.2 MoO x -Ru/C and 0.5 MoO x -Ru/C than Ru/C catalyst further confirm the crucial role of Mo species in inhibiting the cleavage of C–C bonds. Based on these results, the reduced hydrocracking activity of MoO x -Ru/C could be attributed to its unique catalyst configuration (Fig. 8(e)), in which the highly dispersed MoO x on the Ru metal surface reduced the interaction between catalyst and resulting alkanes, thus inhibiting the adsorption and cracking of metallic Ru to C–C bonds. 4 Conclusions In summary, we reported a highly MoO x -Ru/C bimetallic catalyst for the hydrogenolysis of esters at low temperatures (≤ 150 °C). Benefiting from the mild reaction temperature, the C–C bond cleavage side reaction was largely suppressed and long-chain alkanes with high selectivity were obtained. The high performance of MoO x -Ru/C was mainly attributed to its unique structure that maximizes the MoO x -Ru active interfaces, i.e. highly dispersed MoO x species enhance the interaction between MoO x -Ru/C and esters, while adjacent Ru sites provide sufficient active hydrogen atoms for the reaction by dissociating H2. Besides, dispersing MoO x on the Ru metal surface weakens the interaction between Ru sites and resulting alkanes, thus significantly reducing the hydrocracking activity towards C–C bonds even at high temperatures of 205 °C. This study provides a facile and novel strategy for designing HDO catalysts with the atomic-scale active interface for the efficient hydrogenolysis of biomass-derived esters to alkanes. coredata.dc:description: The efficient hydrogenolysis of esters to alkanes is the key protocol for producing advanced biofuels from renewable plant oils or fats. Due to the low reactivity of the carbonyl group in esters, a high reaction temperature (>250 °C) is the prerequisite to ensure high conversion of esters. Here, we report a highly dispersed MoO x -Ru/C bimetallic catalyst for the efficient hydrogenolysis of esters to alkanes under 150 °C. The optimal catalyst exhibits >99% conversion of methyl stearate and 99% selectivity to diesel-range alkanes, reaching a high rate of up to 2.0 mmol gcat –1 h–1, 5 times higher than that of Ru/C catalyst (MoO x /C is inert). Integrated experimental and theoretical investigations attribute the high performance to the abundant MoO x -Ru interfacial sites on the catalyst surface, which offers high activity for the C–O cleavage of esters. Furthermore, the dispersed MoO x species significantly weaken the hydrocracking activity of the metallic Ru for C–C bonds, thus yielding alkane products without carbon loss. This study provides a facile and novel strategy for the design of high-performance heterogeneous catalysts for the hydrodeoxygenation of biomass-derived esters to alkane products.
